newsitem.title: RUSSIA: St Petersburg plans Eurobond late Jan/early Feb.
newsitem.headline: St Petersburg plans Eurobond late Jan/early Feb.

text.p: Russia's second city of St Petersburg plans to start distribution of a Eurobond at the end of this month or early in February, the official Itar-Tass news agency said on Tuesday.
St Petersburg mayor Vladimir Yakovlev told Tass the city would initially issue $100 million of bonds with a maturity running between two and five years.
This would be followed by another $300 million issue, and if they are successful the city would issue further Eurobonds in 1998, it quoted him as saying.
St Petersburg has mandated U.S. investment bank Salomon Bros to lead the Eurobond issue.
The city is still waiting for a credit rating from one of the international rating agencies.

Russia issued a heavily oversubscribed $1 billion five-year Eurobond last November, marking its first return to international capital markets since the 1917 revolution, in the biggest ever debut sovereign Eurobond.
But it is still unclear to what extent the federal government will authorise, guarantee or tax issues by other Russian borrowers.
St Petersburg regularly issues rouble municipal bonds, but officials believe international borrowing would be cheaper.
The cities of Moscow and Nizhny Novgorod, and the region of Sverdlovsk have also announced plans to issue Eurobonds.
